13 Constantin Brancusi St | Complex Potcoava, Bucharest 030424
Doctor Joseph Lister, no. 1, sector 5, Bucharest 050541
The concept of CAJU by Joseph Hadad brasserie is casual dining, with affordable price dishes, which caters to different levels of customers.
Clean, bright and modern setting with comfortable seating either inside or out on their balcony. Small menu but with plenty of choice for most tastes.
ONLY THE BEST FOOD, THE BEST MUSICIANS, THE BEST GUESTS. May it be with a glass of wine, watching one charming sunset. May it be with one of our special made desserts.
A small and cozy place with delicious food and drinks (one of the best I\'ve had so far). The hosts are very friendly and careful so you can have a great time in their company.
Really recommend the place if you wanna have a good time with fiends or family. I have ordered the Saint Louis (hope i got the name right) Ribs and they were great.

This place is a true gem. Located in the center of Bucharest, it\'s easy to reach and a very pleasant restaurant, for both business and private events (I was there with some friends, but it\'s cozy and elegant, so it would work as well for small parties or business meals).
The Waiters are slow when they have to take your order but, the order come quick and the check as well. Nice atmosphere the waiter smile missing

We were surprised to find this place while wandering around old town. Excellent space with really good music, friendly staff, amazing cocktails and just an easy place to spend some time and eat/drink something.

A nice restaurant, on the top floor of a building in the area between Gara de Nord and Victoriei Square. Nice view and terrace, especially in the summer. Interesting menu, food is pretty good. They have lunch menus that are ok for business lunches.
The food is very good and the place it is very nice. You can have several features that remind Italy. The place is clean and silent, being located near the center of Bucharest.

The biggest wellness, relaxation and entertainment center in Europe. Located North of Bucharest, just 10 minutes away from the city, Therme București is a wellness concept for a modern lifestyle, dedicated to your well-being.
Biggest aqua park in Romania Unique features, such as the slides variety, wave pool, sandy beach, private pavilions, changing rooms with showers and lockers,etc.
Edenland Park represents the ideal destination for adventure in nature, relaxation and fun with family or friends.
The MUSEUM of SENSES is home to an experience that will awaken your senses and inspire you to discover more and, therefore, to feel more.

The tourist bus line (during spring-autumn) is comprised of 4 special sightseeing busses (with open rooftop), each with a capacity of 77 seats, which run on the following route: Piaţa Presei, Muzeul Satului, Arcul de Triumf, Piaţa Victoriei
AFI Cotroceni, Bulevardul General Vasile Milea 4, București 061344
A colossal parliament building known for its ornate interior composed of 23 sections, it houses the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies, three museums and an international conference center.
The Village Museum (Muzeul Satului in Romanian) is an open-air ethnographic museum located in the Herăstrău Park (Bucharest, Romania), showcasing traditional Romanian village life.
The first, wooden, triumphal arch was built hurriedly, after Romania gained its independence (1878), so that the victorious troops could march under it.
The Romanian Athenaeum (Romanian: Ateneul Român) is a concert hall in the center of Bucharest, Romania and a landmark of the Romanian capital city.

The building that currently houses the bookstore was built at the beginning of the 20th century by the Chrissoveloni bankers family. During the first few decades of its existence the building housed the Chrissoveloni Bank headquarters, and afterwards it became a general store.
The Cișmigiu Gardens or Cișmigiu Park (Romanian: Grădinile Cișmigiu or Parcul Cișmigiu) are a public park near the center of Bucharest, Romania, spanning areas on all sides of an artificial lake.

The park was initially intended to be called Parcul Național, but it was renamed Parcul Carol II during the period of the Carol II of Romania's personality cult. Following World War II, it was renamed Parcul I. V. Stalin, featuring a statue of Stalin at its entrance. The park was renamed and the statue was torn down in 1956 as part of the De-Stalinization in Romania.

Carol Park (Romanian: Parcul Carol) is a public park in Bucharest, Romania, named after King Carol I of Romania. A French garden located in the southern-central area of Bucharest, partly on Filaret hill,[1] originally capable of hosting various exhibitions, it suffered considerable modifications during the communist regime, including a name change to Parcul Libertății (Liberty Park).

Aside from green areas, the park contains a number of playgrounds as well as a navigable lake, utilised by leisure boats in summer. Tineretului Park contains the Sala Polivalentă, one of Bucharest's largest multi-purpose halls, used for concerts and indoor sporting events.
Oh Alexandru Ioan, where would I be without you, the cleanliness of the park and the utter beauty, what a gem in the middle of sector 3. Excellent for walking, biking, people watching, and jogging.

Mogoșoaia Palace (in Romanian: Palatul Mogoșoaia, pronounced [paˈlatul moɡoˈʃo̯aja]) is situated about 10 kilometres from Bucharest, Romania. It was built between 1698-1702 by Constantin Brâncoveanu in what is called the Romanian Renaissance style or Brâncovenesc style. The palace bears the name of the widow of the Romanian boyar Mogoș, who owned the land it was built on

A small park in the West Side of Bucharest, Drumul Taberei neighborhood. From 2015 it has a new look, lookin' modern than the older one. It is located in a green neighborhood, Drumul Taberei, in the District 6 of Bucharest.

This is one of the few wonderful natural parks of Bucharest, with a natural created lake in the middle. You can have a nice long walk anytime during the year. Particularly during the summer this is the only place where you can admire the Nile Lotus.
